lexUnit.name: shatter.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: cause to separate into many pieces due to a sharp impact.

sentence.text: When the camera crew arrived three days later , the shelter was covered in graffiti and all its glass had been shattered .
Also on the floor were three or four framed pictures which had been trampled stamped upon , so that the frames were broken and the glass shattered to fragments .
Some of the panes in the lower windows had been shattered by flood .
Marion Howells and her daughter Kayleigh were asleep just a few feet from a window which was shattered by the blasts .
Windows were shattered in the blast , at Farnham Street in the Catholic lower Ormeau area .

Gradually you saw this self-absorbed monarch stripped down of all his trappings , until a wonderful scene when he was kneeling on the ground staring at his reflection , and suddenly he shattered the mirror against his foreheard .
Drachenfels moved among them , laughing as he squeezed heads in his hands and shattered them like rotted fruits .
A few strategic blows with a hammer will achieve this without shattering the whole thing , but it 's prudent to first bail out as much water as possible from the trap .
The executioner , using an iron bar three feet long and two inches square , would strike the limb over each hollow , thereby shattering each arm and leg in two places .
To be broken on the wheel was a horrific and prolonged execution , the victim 's limbs being slowly and systematically shattered with an iron bar , a final blow to the chest bringing merciful death
This involved the felon having his limbs shattered by iron bars , inflicting excruciating agony until death ensued .
The cupboard doors had all been deeply hacked and scored with a knife , every crisp bag had been burst , every stick of rock shattered and splintered : it was a very thorough job .
